subject: Writing code (was RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy)
msgSnippet: ... Why, right is right however one arrives at it. Just cos it isn t proven, doesn t make it not right. Why not accept good fortune occasionally? ... I have
messageBody:
Ilja wrote:

> To me a conclusion which might be right out of plain luck *is*
> irrelevant.

Why, right is right however one arrives at it. Just 'cos it isn't proven,
doesn't make it not right. Why not accept good fortune occasionally?

> I write code, I test my code, I debug my code when tests fail
> by trying to analyse the output. I was hoping for it to be
> easier to analyse, w/o a lot of manual effort, but I don't
> have an itch big enough to attempt to write such a tool --
> especially when it'd be cheap/clean to do it in the
> framework.

> So you are actually concerned about who will be writing the code to make
> it work?

I have open source projects I help out with, I think the bigger test is the
community of folk you work with. If I am this out of synch with you all it
isn't a good start. There are many reason why software projects fail, and I
don't need to start one that appears so unwelcomed by the development team
for the product (that I like/use so much) that I was hoping to assist w/
"my little epiphany".

> Also, much as I could craft some sort of add on
> (perhaps leverage my own sub-class from TestCase) I think it
> needs too much of what is in the framework in order to work
> well, and I don't fancy re-writing the thing.

> I don't think you'd need to rewrite anything.

But I do, and if I am writing it that matters more. Few people here have
even accepted the need for the concept, and other than "go write you own
collectors" not offered help, so why would I waste time on the
implementation?

> I use eclipse, I use ant -- I like the integration into those
> tools more than I like my idea. If I can't get you to
> contemplate the concept, then I probably have little chance
> of persuading them. If they don't use it, I won't benefit. Another
> reason not to start.

You wouldn't need to persuade anyone. Both Eclipse and Ant are open
source and have a quite mature plugin concept.

Yes, I know, I've written for both. I'm hardly going to try to replicate all
the work for both plugins just to try to get this point over.

> This was my first topic on this mailing list, and much as you
> were pretty measured/polite (at least at the start) I don't
> think I'll be back for more. Open Source is (IMHO) about open
> minded discussion of ideas, and I don't think I found that
> here. No worries, have fun w/ what you do.

> It is also about contribution. I think we would all be pleased to see
> you write your tool and happy to help you where we can. If it proves to
> be valuable to many people, the best way to distribute it could be
> reconsidered.

Sorry, I've heard that too many times before. Sure, it is a filter of who
wants to put skin in the game, but it can also be used as an easy barrier.
Yes, I know it is "part of OSS the process -- the trial by code production",
but it doesn't make it always right & I am not sure it is right here.

If the community of developers/users on a project isn't open to accepting a
core change [and I feel that is the default reaction here -- right or wrong]
then it doesn't making it a welcoming environment to want to invest to much
effort. As such, what could be done as an internal change gets relegated to
a large external development. Sorry, as I've stated before -- I wanted to
clean up some ugly reporting mess, not re-write a testing tool.

> No hard feelings,

Glad you feel that way.

regards

Adam
